# The evolution of public taste in music through the 21st century

![](images/clipboard-3938451565.png){width="297"}

Understanding the evolution of public taste in musics gives us insights into broader cultural shifts and trends. The analysis of streaming data would show the changes in the popularity of different music genres in different time and this can reflect the shifts in cultural preferences. Music can act as a cultural and economic force. The public preferences for popular songs can implicate some social and economic implications, this relates to consumer spending habits, brand perception and even political attitudes. Public preferences directly influence the success of artists, labels, streaming platforms,etc By tracking changes in popular song preferences, stakeholders in the music industry can adapt their strategies to meet evolving consumer demands.

There are 3 data visualizations in the following paragraphs, which include a **trend line**, a **pie chart** and an **interactive bar chart**.

## Trend lines of each genre from 2000 - 2023

```{r,eval=FALSE,echo=TRUE}
# Load necessary libraries
library(ggplot2)
library(dplyr)
library(tidyverse)

songs_data <- read.csv("/Users/shawnji/Documents/billboard_used.csv")
songs_data
# Define the dataset
# Assuming your dataset is named 'songs_data'
# Make sure the 'Year' column is in numeric format
songs_data$Year <- as.numeric(songs_data$Year)

# Filter the dataset for the specified years (2000-2001)
filtered_data <- songs_data %>%
  filter(Year >= 2000 & Year <= 2023)

# Define the genres of interest
genres_of_interest <- c('r&b', 'pop', 'hip pop', 'salsa', 'soul', 'rock', 'country', 'neo')

# Initialize an empty data frame to store genre counts
genre_counts <- data.frame(Year = numeric(), Genres = character())

# Loop through each genre and calculate the count for each year
for(genre in genres_of_interest) {
  genre_data <- filtered_data %>%
    filter(grepl(genre, Genres, ignore.case = TRUE)) %>%
    group_by(Year) %>%
    summarise(Count = n())
  genre_counts <- bind_rows(genre_counts, genre_data)
}

# Plot the trend lines
ggplot(genre_counts, aes(x = Year, y = Count, color = Genres)) +
  geom_line() +
  labs(title = "Genre Trends Over Years",
       x = "Year",
       y = "Number of Songs") +
  scale_color_manual(values = c('r&b' = 'blue', 'pop' = 'red', 'hip pop' = 'green', 
                                'salsa' = 'orange', 'soul' = 'purple', 'rock' = 'brown',
                                'country' = 'pink', 'neo' = 'cyan')) +
  theme_minimal()
```

# Data Visualization

```{r,eval=TRUE,echo=TRUE}
# Load necessary libraries
library(dplyr)
library(ggplot2)

# Load the dataset
data <- read.csv("/Users/shawnji/Documents/billboard_used.csv", stringsAsFactors = FALSE)

# Function to extract genres from bracket notation
extract_genres <- function(genre_string) {
  gsub("[\\[\\]']", "", genre_string) %>% 
    strsplit(", ") %>% 
    unlist()
}

# Apply the function to the dataset
data$Genres <- lapply(data$Genres, extract_genres)

# Filter data for the year 2000
data_2000 <- data %>%
  filter(Year == 2000)

# Count the occurrences of specified genres in 2000
genre_counts_2000 <- table(unlist(data_2000$Genres))

# Specify the 8 genres
specified_genres <- c('r&b', 'pop', 'hip pop', 'salsa', 'soul', 'rock', 'country', 'neo')

# Get the counts for specified genres
genre_counts_2000_specified <- genre_counts_2000[specified_genres]

# Get the top 5 most popular genres in 2000
top_genres_2000 <- names(sort(genre_counts_2000_specified, decreasing = TRUE))

# Calculate percentages for each specified genre in 2000
genre_percentages_2000 <- round(100 * genre_counts_2000_specified / sum(genre_counts_2000_specified), 1)

# Plot pie chart for 2000
pie(genre_counts_2000_specified, 
    labels = paste(top_genres_2000, genre_percentages_2000, "%"),
    main = "Most Popular Music Genres in 2000",
    col = rainbow(length(genre_counts_2000_specified)))

# Filter data for the year 2022
data_2022 <- data %>%
  filter(Year == 2022)

# Count the occurrences of specified genres in 2022
genre_counts_2022 <- table(unlist(data_2022$Genres))

# Get the counts for specified genres
genre_counts_2022_specified <- genre_counts_2022[specified_genres]

# Get the top 5 most popular genres in 2022
top_genres_2022 <- names(sort(genre_counts_2022_specified, decreasing = TRUE))

# Calculate percentages for each specified genre in 2022
genre_percentages_2022 <- round(100 * genre_counts_2022_specified / sum(genre_counts_2022_specified), 1)

# Plot pie chart for 2022
pie(genre_counts_2022_specified, 
    labels = paste(top_genres_2022, genre_percentages_2022, "%"),
    main = "Most Popular Music Genres in 2022",
    col = rainbow(length(genre_counts_2022_specified)))
```
